metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Leaf area index of Daman Superstation, 2018)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Daman superstation in the middle reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from June 11 to September 18 in 2018. The site (100.372° E, 38.856°N) was located in the maize surface, near Zhangye city in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. There are 3 observation samples, each of which is about 30m×30m in size, and the latitude and longitude ranges are (100.373297°E~100.374205°E, 38.857871°N~38.858390°N), (100.373918°E~100.373897°E, 38.854025°). N~38.854941°N), (100.368007°E~100.369044°E, 38.850678°N~38.851580°N). Five sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The LAI data is obtained from LAINet measurements following four steps: (1) the raw data is light quantum (level 0); (2) the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); (3) the invalid and null values are screened and using the 7 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); (4) for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Qu et al. (2014) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure leaf area index in agricultural areas within arid regions?
Example.Answer: The leaf area index in agricultural areas within arid regions, such as the Daman superstation in the Heihe River Basin, is measured using a wireless sensor network called LAINet. This method involves the automatic acquisition of light data at each node on an hourly basis, which is then processed to calculate daily leaf area index values.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of the challenges faced in data collection for ecological studies in arid and semi-arid inland river basins?
Example.Answer: Ecological studies in arid and semi-arid inland river basins, such as those along the Silk Road, face challenges like the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges complicate data collection efforts in regions like the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems comprises data collected from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, established since 2012. This dataset is available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center and includes energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes?
Definition.Answer: In the context of measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, an 'eddy covariance system' is a method used to obtain half-hourly turbulent flux data. It involves measuring the fluctuations in wind velocity and scalar quantities like temperature and gas concentrations to estimate the exchange rates of energy, water vapor, and carbon dioxide between the land surface and the atmosphere.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'oasis–desert system' in the context of ecological and agricultural studies?
Definition.Answer: In the context of ecological and agricultural studies, an 'oasis–desert system' refers to a unique ecological landscape found in arid and semi-arid areas, where oases serve as the core of ecological environments and are crucial for economic development. They support the majority of the population and play a significant role in maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity, especially in the desert areas of western China.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for leaf area index using a wireless sensor network compare to those for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange using an eddy covariance system?
Comparison.Answer: The leaf area index data is collected using a wireless sensor network (LAINet) that automatically captures light data at multiple nodes, processed to compute LAI values. In contrast, energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data are collected using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, focusing on fluxes with half-hourly data intervals.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred for processing raw observational data to ensure accuracy and reliability in hydrometeorological and vegetation studies?
Interpretation.Answer: Data processing and quality control procedures are essential and are divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. For example, the datasets use software to process raw observational data to filter out invalid values and apply a sliding average to mitigate the effects of weather variability.

Interpretation.Question: How might challenges such as ecological degradation and land desertification influence the design and deployment of data collection networks in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges like ecological degradation and land desertification necessitate the implementation of long-term observational datasets and the establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations to monitor and understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, ensuring ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: What strategies can be implemented to effectively integrate data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems to support ecological and socioeconomic goals?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating long-term datasets from artificial and natural systems involves collecting comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, alongside hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. This integration supports the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases by providing quantitative insights into oasis–desert interactions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it essential to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable oasis development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial to achieving sustainable development goals because oases are integral to the ecological environment and economic foundation in arid and semi-arid areas. Understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems is vital for carbon peaking, carbon neutrality, ecological security, and the sustainable development of the oasis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying challenges make data collection in arid and semi-arid inland river basins difficult?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data collection in arid and semi-arid inland river basins is challenging due to ecological degradation issues such as drying rivers and lakes, natural vegetation loss, intensified desertification, and frequent dust storms. These environmental challenges, especially prevalent in regions like the Tarim River basin and others along the Silk Road, complicate the efforts to gather consistent and reliable observational data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to employ a wireless sensor network like LAINet for collecting leaf area index data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Employing a wireless sensor network like LAINet is important because it provides detailed, automated, and continuous observations of leaf area index, which is crucial for understanding surface processes and ecological dynamics in arid and semi-arid regions like the Heihe River Basin. These areas are significant for maintaining ecological stability and supporting economic development, particularly in oasis-desert systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of maintaining long-term observational datasets involving energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals of maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis-desert ecosystems include understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange to achieve sustainable oasis development, support the goals of carbon peaking and neutrality, and protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to have a comprehensive observational network for collecting hydrometeorological and vegetation data in inland river basins within arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: A comprehensive observational network is necessary in inland river basins within arid regions to address the ecological degradation challenges such as drying rivers, land desertification, and dust storms. This network provides crucial data that help in managing water resources, understanding ecological dynamics, and supporting sustainable development in these vulnerable areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to collect and process data for leaf area index measurement in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the field, a wireless sensor network called LAINet is used to automatically collect light data from each node on a daily hourly basis (Level0). This raw data is processed using specialized software to calculate daily LAI for each node (Level1). Further processing involves identifying and filling invalid values and applying a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather variations' impact on LAI calculations (Level2). For areas with multiple nodes, the average value from all nodes represents the final observation for that area (Level3).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems compiled and maintained over time?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Observational datasets consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data from artificial and natural oasis-desert systems. The datasets include turbulent flux data obtained every half-hour by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. Hydrometeorological data, such as radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, are collected from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. The data maintenance process involves systematic data collection, processing, and data archiving and sharing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methods for ensuring data quality in hydrometeorological and vegetation datasets collected from oasis-desert regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality in hydrometeorological and vegetation datasets is ensured through a comprehensive data processing and quality control protocol. The procedure includes collecting data from automatic weather stations and other instruments, processing the data to identify and fill invalid values, and applying statistical methods such as moving averages to smooth out variations caused by environmental factors. Additionally, the datasets are archived and shared, allowing for ongoing verification and validation.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the comprehensive observation of leaf area index in the context of the Heihe River Basin?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the Leaf Area Index wireless sensor network (LAINet) has enabled the comprehensive observation of leaf area index in the Heihe River Basin by automatically acquiring sunlight data at each node daily and hourly.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary to conduct long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert ecosystems require a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural systems, including half-hourly turbulent flux data acquired by eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, and hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple observation nodes within a sample plot enhance the accuracy of environmental data collection in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multiple observation nodes within a sample plot enhances the accuracy of environmental data collection by averaging the data across multiple nodes, which helps to account for variability and provide a more representative final observation for the plot.

Expectation.Question: Why might long-term observational datasets be crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: A long-term observational dataset provides a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases. It supports the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis by achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might researchers face when collecting data in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms. These challenges can affect data collection efforts.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using multiple nodes in a leaf area index wireless sensor network for data collection?
Expectation.Answer: Using multiple nodes in a leaf area index wireless sensor network allows for more comprehensive data collection, as it enables the calculation of daily LAI by processing raw data to identify and fill invalid values and apply a 7-day moving average to reduce the impact of weather changes on LAI calculations. The average of multiple nodes' data provides a more reliable observation value for the sub-area.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using a wireless sensor network for collecting leaf area index data in terms of accuracy and data integrity?
Judgmental.Answer: The wireless sensor network (LAINet) appears to be an effective method for collecting leaf area index data, as it allows for automated and continuous data acquisition. The data processing includes identifying and filling invalid values and applying a 7-day sliding average to mitigate the influence of weather changes, which enhances data integrity and accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the potential for expanding the existing datasets by integrating additional variables or data sources, and how might this improve our understanding of oasis–desert interactions?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating additional variables such as methane fluxes, more detailed soil parameters, or remote sensing data could enhance the existing datasets. This expansion could provide a more comprehensive understanding of oasis–desert interactions by capturing a wider range of ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric processes, ultimately supporting better ecological and socioeconomic development strategies.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the data collection method can effectively capture the leaf area index over time in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: The leaf area index data is collected using a wireless sensor network (LAINet), which automatically captures light data at each node daily and hourly. This data is then processed to calculate daily LAI, identify and fill in invalid values, and apply a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather influences, ultimately providing processed Level3 data.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in collecting accurate long-term energy and carbon exchange data in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include ecological degradation such as drying rivers, degraded vegetation, desertification, and dust storms, which are prevalent in inland river basins like the Tarim River basin. These conditions complicate the maintenance and accuracy of long-term observations necessary for understanding energy and carbon exchanges.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how a dataset from oasis-desert systems can include such a wide range of parameters like hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset includes parameters from a suite of observational data collected using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. Hydrometeorological data is gathered from automatic weather stations, and vegetation and soil parameters are supplemented to provide comprehensive insights from 11 established stations in the region.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and describe data collection methods employed for capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid and semiarid oasis–desert systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods include using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. Hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles are observed from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. Additionally, groundwater table data and supplementary vegetation and soil parameters are collected.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the challenges faced in the data collection process for monitoring the ecological environment of inland river basins in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in inland river basins like the Tarim River basin and others westward along the Silk Road.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of potential datasets available for studying the interactions between oasis and desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include long-term observational data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, consisting of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. These datasets are freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center and cover the middle and lower reaches of the HRB in the arid regions of western China.
